social_posts.post_text:
My lesson plan is not some well-crafted masterpiece. It is simply choosing a book to share with students, and then sharing it. 
 
People are impressed by the lessons where students are doing, and making, and solving; many tend to place more value on the activities where students are busy DOING something; active learning some would say; hands-on learning others might call it. 
 
And, don’t get me wrong, there is great value in all of that; just not more so than kids sitting on a carpet listening to their teacher read aloud. 
 
There is value to the fellowship that comes with the gathering of the classroom community on the carpet; there is value in the stillness that comes when students are entranced by the musical rhythm of reading; there is value in the vocabulary that ripples off the page and flows from the teachers lips; there is value in the synapses firing and electricity pulsing through the imagination to build images from those words; there is value in the showmanship that comes in reading aloud – a nuanced performance of character voices mixed with gestures both wild and subtle giving a breath and a heartbeat to a book; there is a magic and an art to the way reading skills like prediction and use of context clues can reveal themselves gently through a read aloud; the way literary devices like alliteration, puns, and flashback unfold naturally; there is value in the advertisement of books and authors and illustrators you present to your audience – a world you unlock; the gift of discovering all of the other books from that author or that series have disappeared from the shelves because of YOUR kind introduction to students; there is value in the connections students make with themes – those messages that stick with kids in their hearts and minds; the messages they will carry on their journey. There is value to the  respite of time reserved for the simple pleasure of hearing a story; taking a break with a good book.
 
Librarian friends, if all you do is read to your students when they visit the library, you have done more than just read. Your work is valuable. Your impact is valuable. You are valuable.

Here’s some Black boy joy for your feed. If you’ve been following, you know my first grade classes are studying illustrators all year long. For Black history month, our featured illustrator is Christian Robinson. Robinson is a modern classic; his picture books are iconic in the same way you can spot the art of classic children’s book illustrators like Eric Carle, Leo Lionni, or Jerry Pinkney. We read, The Last Stop on Market Street and drew CJ for our illustrators portfolio. One of my favorite scenes in the book is when CJ closes his eyes and the guitar music on the bus lets him imagine the birds and butterflies soaring overhead in the sunshine. Swipe for a beautiful collection of Robinson’s books to start adding to your collection today. #blackboyjoy #blackhistorymonth #illustrator #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

The NEA’s Read Across America has shifted its focus to a year long celebration highlighting 12 themes in the 2022-23 year. Still, many schools continue a day or week or even month long celebration in March. I’ve taken the twelve themes and created a menu in Google Slides with four book choices for each theme. All images of book covers are linked to digital books on epic, so if you don’t already have a free educator account, be sure to create one. Also, when you make a copy of the slides - link in bio- you’ll be able to fully edit the menu to tailor it to your specific needs. Depending on how long you celebrate, you can use this menu in a variety of configurations… there’s no right or wrong way. I’ve provided a suggested template you might try for the week you celebrate (swipe to the end to see). Most importantly, we should read books with/to our students that show them a broad perspective of the world and the identities and experiences of people in our global community. #readacrossamerica #nea #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

When you look at the contributions of Frank Morrison’s work to children’s literature, you see vibrant images of Black people both real (Muhammad Ali, George Washington Carver, Aretha Franklin, Pelé) and imagined (Kick Push and I Got the Rhythm); he helps tell stories of Black joy, struggle, and power with a distinct style – if hip-hop music was translated into illustrations, you can imagine Morrison’s work. As an illustrator who started his journey with a can of spray paint tagging walls with graffiti, we are reminded that art – whether sprayed on the concrete walls of an underpass or decorated with awards on the cover of a children’s book – is telling us a story; a story of people. People who want to be heard, seen, affirmed. As you continue to celebrate Black history all year long, be sure to invest in and highlight Morrison’s work. @frankmorrison #blackhistorymonth #illustrator #illustratorsoninstagram #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

History is intersectional. Identities and histories of people overlap.  You don’t have to wait to highlight queer folks in June or Black folks in February. And, this account, is not just about school and classroom libraries… it’s about home libraries. If your school is removing books, make sure you’re filling your home with them. Parents, it’s just as much your responsibility to share these true stories with your kids as it is for educators. 

🏳️‍🌈✊🏾 Bayard Rustin, a gay Black man, is responsible for organizing a quarter million people for the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom where Martin Luther King Jr. gave his seminal I Have A Dream speech. 

🏳️‍🌈✊🏾 At age 29, Alvin Ailey choreographed Revelations - a modern dance ballet - that has been performed for 23 million people worldwide including performances at presidential inaugurations and opening ceremonies for the Olympic Games. 

🏳️‍🌈✊🏾 Marsha P. Johnson was a prominent figure in the Stonewall Riots which began the modern day fight for gay liberation.  A revolutionary, Johnson fought for gay liberation and trans rights while also being an outspoken AIDS activist. #blackhistorymonth #blackhistory #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

Do you ever have kids ask, “Do I have to do this?” I try to reframe their thinking, to “I GET to do this!” It’s easy for anyone - kids and adults alike - to take things for granted. After reading The Oldest Student: How Mary Walker Learned to Read, I hope that students understand that not everyone has/had the same opportunities or the same access to education. This was the perfect book to share on the cusp of transitioning from Black History Month and Women’s History Month.  Mary teaches us that it’s never too late to chase down your dreams, even at the age of 116. #blackhistorymonth #blackhistory #womenshistorymonth #womenshistory #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

When they say, “You’re so gay,” or “That’s so gay,” they mean to put you down; to insult you; to make you feel bad about yourself. But behind their intention to hurt you, there is a power to the words; if you’re gay – or even if you’re not – know that gay is good, and these books about real gay people can show you just how good. Take a look… it’s in a book… a reading rainbow. #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo #memes #teachermemes #funny #education #teachergram #iteachtoo #teacherlife #gay #lgbtq

Today we read The Girl Who Thought in Pictures: The Story of Dr. Temple Grandin with soundscape from @novel_effect. Living with autism, Dr. Grandin, faced bullying from classmates in school, and as a woman in the male dominated field of agriculture, she encountered many men who wouldn’t take a chance on her thoughtful ideas and clever designs to improve farms. We are adding this portrait of Grandin to our illustrator’s portfolio. Want the step by step directions for the drawing? Grab it free at the link in bio. #womenshistorymonth #templegrandin

Nichelle Nichols played the part of Uhura on Star Trek. Although it wasn’t a leading role it was a part that shifted white people’s perceptions about Black women, and one that gave the Black community a positive role model reflected back from the TV screen. Fighting against racial discrimination, Nichols almost quit the show until a surprise fan - Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. - convinced her how her small part on Star Trek was making a BIG impact in ways she wasn’t even aware. Nichols went on to do even bigger things in space including helping lead a campaign to diversify NASA’s astronaut candidates to include women and people of color. If you get the chance to read and share Nichols’ story - To Boldly Go - you’ll find it’s out of this world.  @angeladalton_author #startrek #boldlygo #uhura #womenshistorymonth #nasa #space #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

Levels can be useful, they shouldn’t be limiting ⭐️If a student is assessed (MAP) and a reading level is determined (Lexile Level), that information can be a valuable tool to help a teacher measure growth or determine needs or plan for instruction, but it should not limit students. At my school we have many students who perform well on standardized tests. If these tests determine students can read complex, higher level texts, it can be damaging to limit those students to read only texts with high Lexile levels. Swipe through to see some examples. Don’t let levels kill the joy of reading. #read
👀 just one look

This may be a hard pill to swallow for many parents, teachers, & librarians, but if we are being honest, there will be kids who don’t love to read, and in the end, that’s okay. There are adults – perhaps even you – who don’t choose reading as a pleasure activity. They don’t find it enjoyable or relaxing, and that’s okay.
 What’s most important, is that a kid learns HOW to read. Being a good reader will help them successfully complete necessary academic work and everyday tasks in the real world. 
 
This is not to say we – as librarians and teachers and parents – don’t try to instill the love of reading: expose them to a wide variety of genres; give them voice and choice; model our own reading joy at home and in the classroom; provide access to a wide variety of print, eBook, and audio formats; start reading routines to build a reading culture at home at an early age.
 
We may like to curl up with a novel holding “real” book in our hands and flipping the pages for hours on end getting so lost in the story that we forget time exists. But, for our students, reading may be listening to an audio book in small chunks; reading may be flipping through a guide to learn strategies of how to level-up on their favorite video game; reading may be browsing a magazine or nonfiction text and only reading the captions of the pictures; reading may be looking at diagrams that show them how to write code, make a craft, bake a cake, or build a Lego set; reading may be holding an iPad or Kindle or swiping and scrolling through social media posts; reading may be enjoying a graphic novel or a picture book with images that help them better understand the story; reading may be only reading fantasies with wizards and witches or reading may be only enjoying stories based in reality. 
 
When we say we want kids to love reading, we often mean we want kids to love it the way WE love it. But if we stand a chance of getting them to love reading, we must be open to the idea that it’s  probably going to look different than our own love. And if they don’t love it – accept them as they are and know that as long as they CAN read, everything will be okay in the end.

Today someone asked, “Why don’t we learn about Christmas?” I responded, “Raise your hand if you know about or celebrate Christmas.” All the hands went up. I said, “Now leave your hand up if you celebrate or have heard about Ramadan.” All the hands went down. I reminded the boy of the story we read in December that spoke of Hanukkah and Christmas. I reminded him of the display of Christmas books in the library during December. I reminded him that all holidays are important, and we highlight all stories in the library. I told him how I was an adult when I learned about Ramadan, when a young Muslim student at our school was fasting for the first time just like the girl in Lailah’s Lunchbox.  It was my first year as librarian and she came to the library during lunch each day, and she taught me about Ramadan. Now, they, as young people will know about it early on and be able to show respect to classmates and neighbors who celebrate too. #ramadan
I’ll stand by you. #transdayofvisibility #transgender #lgbtq

Trending. When I was a young boy I wanted to play with my sister’s Barbie dolls. The hair; the fashion; the glamour. But playing with ugly Barbie (the one with the really bad haircut) and sitting just beyond the threshold of the doorway to my sister’s room were the conditions of play. My mom eventually got me my own Glamour Gal doll, and my sister is taking me with her to see Taylor Swift this month so we’ve more than made up for withholding Barbie. It’s National School Library Month.  I am sharing That Book Woman by Heather Henson and David Small. Based on the pack horse librarians of Kentucky during the Great Depression, the story shows us how these librarians went to great lengths to bring books to families in isolated, rural areas. Illiterate Cal is skeptical of the book woman and hesitant to see books as more than pages of chicken scratch, but with time and a long winter, his curiosity gets the best of him and his sister, Lark, teaches him to read. I choke up every time Cal reads to the librarian at the end, and she tells him that’s all the gift she needs. Swipe to see the other slides and then make a copy at the link in bio. Earlier this year a follower was offended by the word “molested” used in a video that was linked to a Women’s History Month presentation I created which included Maya Angelou. The word was used to describe what happened to Angelou as a young girl. The argument was this word was not a kid-friendly word. News media reports more and more about states (hey Florida) trying to curb the tongues of citizens - particularly in schools - by not saying gay or sharing pronouns or even discussing menstruation - a completely normal, human body function.  Now, most recently, @scholasticinc has asked the author of Love in the Library - Maggie Tokuda-Hall (@maggietokudahall) - to censor the words “virulent racism” in her story about her grandparents’ experience in Japanese internment camps during World War II. Use the words. These words are important. They matter. Call it racism when it is; if you’re gay, say it, and name your pronouns - they are part of who you are; arm kids with words like molestation, consent, and assault so they can protect themselves when you’re not around; discuss bodies and their functions so young people are not afraid of what’s happening as they grow and change. Words matter. They matter in our everyday conversations, and they matter at school board meetings and in government offices and on conference calls with CEOs of major corporations, because these spaces often hold the power to influence change in big ways. Some will say these words are divisive, but they’re wrong. These words make things clear; and clarity is kindness. Use the words. They matter. For more on Tokuda-Hall’s story and Scholastic’s response, check out the article from Publishers Weekly linked in my stories. #racism #words #wordsmatter #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

This young man - now all grown up - messaged me today. I taught him in 2006. He has graduated with his master’s degree in elementary education and accepted a position to teach abroad. As he went on to tell me how I had influenced him: “You saw potential in me that others didn’t, and brought out my love for writing…” I responded that he will likely find that teachers rarely know the long term impact - good or bad - they have on their students, but it sure is nice when, on a random Monday, out of the blue, you get to hear you made a difference. I still have this photo of the two of us ice skating and a letter with a poem he wrote for me at the end of that fifth grade year. I hope that because your students  knew you, they’ll have been changed for good. First grade illustrator portfolios are going home this week.  I made a little card to attach so they could see the faces of the illustrators we learned about this year. 🏳️‍🌈Not once did anyone read a story to me when I was a kid where the characters were LGBTQ+ (except maybe Frog and Toad). 
🏳️‍🌈In school and at home, they did read stories to me about straight, cisgender characters who had “nuclear” families. 
🏳️‍🌈Guess what? It turns out, no matter how many of those stories people read to me, we read together, or I read on my own, I never changed - gay then, gay now, born gay. None of the books ever made me straight even though all the characters in them were.
🏳️‍🌈But none of those books validated who I was and how I was feeling; that I was normal and ok and accepted and valued and seen and worthy of love. 
🏳️‍🌈What if someone had read me a story about a gay man who ran for President; a gay artist, a lesbian scientist, a trans musician, or queer CEO? What if I saw illustrations that showed two men happily married and raising a child of their own? What if I could have chosen a book about a knight who rescues (and falls in love with) a prince?
🏳️‍🌈They’ll have you believe that children’s books with LGBTQ+ characters and themes are filled with pornographic material or sexual content; that reading these stories will “indoctrinate” your child into the queer community. Instead, they’re filled with celebrations of individuality and acceptance, loving families and powerful allies, successful people who overcame hatred and prejudice, and innovative thinkers and their novel and artistic contributions. 
🏳️‍🌈Reading books won’t turn children into something they’re not, but it can help show them who they are. #Pride
When they try to erase our stories, scream louder. We’re not going away. #pride

❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️Our love story is not new. 
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️Tales and art from the ancient worlds of Mesopotamia and Egypt, Greece and Rome, Japan and China have documented our love and our identities long before any camera or social media post could.  
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️Governments have tried to erase our love and our lives with their laws; and religions have tried to demonize our love and our lives with their lies.
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️But we have always persisted whether by throwing bricks or by throwing glitter; we have survived a holocaust – prisoners emblazoned with pink triangles – and a pandemic – left to die while our leaders turned their backs and their eyes and their funds; we have thrived, by claiming our right to marry – love is love is love; we have been beaten down and stood back up; again, and again, and again. 
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️We are not only in big cities. We are small town country girls and suburban men – love thy neighbor no matter where you live; we are your accountant, mechanic, waitress, and banker; we are your son’s teacher and your daughter’s friend and your mother’s doctor; be careful who you hate, it could be someone who takes care of you and those you love.
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️We are not exclusive to one country; one ethnicity; one race; one gender; one time. Our love is human and worldwide and has always existed.  Our love is from the heart, and the soul, and the body.
 
❤️🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️Our love story is not new; it continues.
 
#pride

The Human Rights Campaign (HRC) has declared a state of emergency for the first time in its 40-year history.  There is a direct attack on the LGBTQ+ community taking place in this country; specifically, our trans and queer family within the larger community are being targeted. Our state and local governments are particularly aiming at transgender youth through a historic number of harmful proposed or passed legislation. There is even an unfortunate division among allies and people in the LGBTQ+ community; picking the groups they want to support and turning their backs on others. 
 
Allyship is not á la carte. You don’t get to party with your gay, lesbian, and bi friends at Pride, but also bring your transphobia. You don’t get to be “fine” with your gay brother, lesbian cousin, or bi coworker, but also oppose the nonbinary educator who teaches your son. You don’t get to be the G in LGBTQ+ but turn your back on the transgender community when they need your privilege, voice, and support. An LGBTQ+ ally should be all-in or not at all. 
 
They say, knowledge is power; understanding helps erase fear; if you know someone’s story, you’ll have more empathy for them. I’m learning to be a better ally within the larger LGBTQ+ community, and these trans and queer educators are some of my greatest teachers. Follow along, listen, learn, and act: @teachingoutsidethebinary @growingwithmxt @teachingwithmxt @hey_wes_ @finn.menzies @well_hello_dollyjaye 

#pride #pridemonth #trans #queer #library #librariansofinstagram #librarian #ally

🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️❤️In the picture book, Pride and Joy, the main character, Joy, learns what it means to be an ally to her gay brother and his boyfriend who are taunted and harassed by a homophobic peer at school. The story - written by Dr. Frank J. Sileo and Kate Lum-Potvin and illustrated by Emmi Smid - serves as a great introduction to young people who are looking for ways they can be allies with their LGBTQ2+ family, friends, and classmates. 
 
🏳️‍⚧️🏳️‍🌈❤️Although Joy uses her voice to stand up to a bully and raises money to help the cause she supports, the back matter here includes a note to grown up allies where a few additional ways to demonstrate allyship are suggested including be respectful to the community, be intersectional, keep learning, and make sure your work as an ally is ongoing. 
 
👬👭🧑‍🤝‍🧑Because kids should learn about allyship at an early age, I’ve curated two lists for you – one is Clickable PD: Kids as Allies with links to videos, articles, and lesson plans (found at the link in my bio – then click Google Drive Freebies – then search for the Pride folder), and the other is a collection of book titles for both kids and adults on the topic of allyship. Remember, as an ally, you should stand BESIDE, not IN FRONT of, the marginalized group you are supporting.  Grab the bookmarks in the same folder in Google Drive Freebies. #pridemonth

In Florida and other states across the country, groups of parents are falsely claiming that proposed or passed legislation like the Parental Rights in Education Act,  is meant to protect children. The question to ask is which parents get the rights and what exactly do children need protecting from? There’s an idea here that there is a superior family, and it’s not the ones with two moms or two dads. 🌈 Jonathan and Thomas West (@daddyandpapa) have added an important title to the @akidsbookabout series - A Kids Book About Gay Parents. Here, readers find out scandalous details about how their family  eats pancakes and popcorn, helps with homework and changes diapers, watches movies and rides bikes. Their clear message, “Whatever your family is, it is exactly right and not better or worse than any other family.” I can see how #lgbtq families can be frightening and deserve less rights because they build their families - like most do - on values, tradition, and love.  #pridemonth

text_entities.entity: a kids book about gay parents

social_posts.post_text:
Some people have a mom and a dad. Married. Together. It’s the default setting. Considered right; normal; acceptable; superior even in the eyes of many. But it’s 2023. Families. Are. Different. 
 
Dad and Daddy’s Big Big Family by Seamus Kirst and Karen Bunting from Magination Press – featuring a girl with two dads – does more to explain this concept. Families come in all shapes, sizes, colors, genders, and abilities. Even our extended family can look very different from our immediate family, and sometimes we are born into families, while other times we choose our family with the friends we make along the way. But there is no right or wrong way to be a family. 
 
Why is this deemed such a horrible idea to teach children in schools? It goes back to the notion of supremacy, and that there is one model of a family better than all the others. The idea of a nuclear family with a married mom and dad raising kids together isn’t even what most of our country is anymore; it’s antiquated and far-removed from the reality of kids in schools today. And we, as educators, should be able to openly discuss all types of families. 
 
As we prepare to celebrate Father’s Day next Sunday, remember, some kids have 1 dad, some kids have 2 dads, some kids have a stepdad, some kids are raised by granddads, some kids have lost a dad, some kids never knew their dad, some kids are adopted, some kids are fostered, some kids are missing their deployed dad, some kids are missing their incarcerated dad, some kids don’t like their dad, and some kids are afraid of their dad. Remember that not all kids are like your kids. #fathersday #family #families

A big little girl. Made to feel ashamed. Embarrassed. Humiliated. Unworthy of attention, joy, love, friendship, kindness. Because of her big body. Her bigness makes her feel invisible to others except when classmates need a target for their jokes and mocking. This beautifully crafted picture book by Vashti Harrison, already claiming a spot on my best of 2023, engages young readers with the idea of shifting the narrative about their worth being told to them by others and their own inner voice; a book that empowers youth to reclaim self-love, beauty, and joy with affirmations of body positivity. I love that this book and the others on the list that follows, show kids that we are beautiful in every shape, size, texture, and color. @vashtiharrison #body #bodypositivity
Annual reminder, queer creators wrote and illustrated some of kid lit’s most classic tales. #pridemonth #pride
Persistence is key. I know you know her. #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram

Hope for Ryan White by Dano Moreno and illustrated by Hanna Abbo (from Albert Whitman & Co.) chronicles the true story of a young boy by the name of Ryan White. Moreno gives readers a glimpse into White’s life from the time he is first diagnosed with AIDS in 1984, to the time he dies in 1990. Over those 6 years, author Moreno contrasts the two communities where Ryan and his family resided. It is a book that paints a picture demonstrating how the kindness, compassion, and education of one community made a vast difference in the lives of White and his family versus the prejudice, fear, and hatred of the misinformed community he was forced to leave. It sends a clear message to young people that they have a responsibility to become educated when there is something that draws out fear in themselves and their community. To have information before taking action; and to always act with humanity in mind – your own and others’. 
 
It is a reminder that while AIDS was a plague that attacked the LGBTQ+ community – particularly gay men – HIV/AIDS did not discriminate based on gender, race, or sexual orientation. It’s important to note that although anyone could become infected, because it spread so virulently throughout the gay community, it created even more hostility and fear towards gays. Similarly, because the gay community was so undervalued in the eyes of politicians, government was slow to act. In fact, “The disease that we now call AIDS was first identified 30 years ago in medical journals in 1981 — President Reagan's first year in office. It quickly took hold in the media and in the national consciousness. Yet it wasn't until May 31, 1987, that President Reagan would give his first major address on AIDS.” (San Francisco AIDS Foundation, 2011). 

Because of its association with gay men, so many others also had to suffer the consequences when homophobic government officials withheld funds for education, research, and medical care. If this disease had impacted cisgender straight white males in the same way, research and treatments would have advanced rapidly; instead, over 40 million people have died from AIDS or #AIDS related complications worldwide. #pridemonth

There’s a new addition to the Little Golden Books collection –  Jayylen’s Juneteenth Surprise, by Lavaille Lavette and illustrated by David Wilkerson. The book is the first in what appears to be a new series about a boy named Jayylen (Jayylen’s Christmas Wish releases in September). In the book, Jayylen is ready for his first lesson about Juneteenth. His mother provides Jayylen and his older sister with the origin of the holiday and some details about what it meant to be enslaved, while granddad provides us with background about an instrument called a frottoir and its use in zydeco music to celebrate Juneteenth. When Jayylen discovers one of granddad’s favorite zydeco musicians, Beau Frank, is performing locally, Jayylen wants to convince the musician to surprise his grandfather with a visit to their Juneteenth celebration. 
 
Since June of 2021, when Juneteenth became a nationally recognized holiday, the publication of picture books about the holiday has steadily increased. I hope that you can find one of these (see the collection included in the slides that follow) to read and share with your class (if you’re still in school) or family on Monday. In fact, you can find and make a copy of a Google Slide with embedded videos at the link in my bio. The slide includes videos that help provide additional information about Juneteenth (from Peacock Kids) and context for understanding more about the frottoir and zydeco music mentioned in the story. #juneteenth

A Child’s Introduction to Pride from @bdlev books (author @sarahpragerbooks & illustrator @cait_illustrate) reminded me that…
 
…Pride is a love story. 
 
Pride is not about them on the corner with their signs; hissing and spitting venom. That angry mob; furious that we found love in a hopeless place. 
 
They’re mad because for so long we managed to survive and live even in presence of those who made sure to dim our lights; they hoped that one day our candle would flicker and extinguish; they hoped we’d just sizzle into a curl of smoke and drift away unseen. 
 
But we chose to hold onto that flame through the shame, and the prayers, and the laws, and the plagues. We held onto it. 
 
For those who shout, “Why Pride?” We had to fight for the right to marry; we had to fight for medical treatment and care during the AIDS crisis, and we must continue to fight for gender affirming care; we have to fight to be seen in libraries and classrooms; we have to fight for our right to joy dressing up in drag;  we have to fight to be seen as who we say we are: he, she, they; we have to fight to use restrooms and hire caterers and play sports; we have to fight to donate our lifesaving, life-giving blood.
 
We have always had to fight and demand; and you don’t; you didn’t; so that’s why Pride.
 
At the heart of this month, at the core of our love story, there is a celebration of those fights; the ones we’ve won, and the ones we’re still fighting in the name of love.  We have fought with bricks and protests and parades and marches; but we have also fought with lipstick and glitter and dancing and singing; we have fought with kisses on corners and hands held in hospital rooms and hugs held in secret rendevous; fights fought with framed snapshots we tack up in our cubicles or set upon our office desks; we fight in suits on capitol hill or in sparkling drag at library story hour. We fight. To love. To be human. To exist. And we always will.
 
Pride is a love story. Love for our community; love for our husbands and wives and lovers and partners; love for our friends; and – most importantly - love for ourselves. 
 
#pride

❤️Our love story is not new. 
 
❤️Tales and art from the ancient worlds of Mesopotamia and Egypt, Greece and Rome, Japan and China have documented our love and our identities long before any camera or social media post could.  
 
❤️Governments have tried to erase our love and our lives with their laws; and religions have tried to demonize our love and our lives with their lies.
 
❤️But we have always persisted whether by throwing bricks or by tossing confetti; we have survived a holocaust – prisoners emblazoned with pink triangles – and a pandemic – left to die while our leaders turned their backs and their eyes and their funds; we have thrived, by claiming our right to marry – love is love is love; we have been beaten down and stood back up; again, and again, and again. 
 
❤️We are not only in big cities. We are small town country girls and suburban men – love thy neighbor; we are your accountant and your kid’s teacher and your daughter’s friend and your mother’s doctor; be careful who you hate, it could be someone who takes care of you and those you love.
 
❤️We are not exclusive to one country; one ethnicity; one race; one gender; one time.
Our love is human and worldwide and has always existed.
Our love is from the heart, and the soul, and the body.
 
❤️Our love story is not new; it continues. 
 
#anniversary #7

Freddie Mercury is one of the most recent additions to the Little People, Big Dreams series by Maria Isabel Sánchez Vegara. What I like most about this book about the legendary Queen performer, is it does not leave out important parts of Freddie’s identity that you might expect a children’s book to leave out - including his late-in-life relationship with Jim and his battle with AIDS. If you’ve never read one of the books from the series, you should know that each title ends with a timeline of the person’s life with accompanying photographs which are a nice contrast to the colorful illustrations throughout the story. Freddie joins about a dozen other queer biographies in the set including Ru Paul, Laverne Cox, Megan Rapinoe, and Alan Turing. Swipe to see others in the LGBTQ+ collection. 
 
NOTE: I already know some have criticized this series for reducing a person to their one crowning achievement, reinforcing stereotypes, or being one-dimensional. For me, I see these books as age-appropriate biographical introductions for young people; doorways to want to know more about someone. These books are not intended to give you an in-depth look at all aspects of a person’s life, but rather an overview. If you’re using these with older kids, you can certainly talk about identity and stereotypes with them, to make sure that they understand this short picture book isn’t all there is to a person. They may not be perfect, but I think they are still worthy of being in your home and school library collections – especially for young readers interested in the lives of real people. #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

In author Juno Dawson’s (@junodawson) debut picture book, You Need to Chill: A Story of Love and Family, (illustrated by @laura_a_hughes), the young narrator tries to squash the inquisition by her classmates who are all very curious about where her brother Bill has gone. Has he been eaten by a shark or a whale? Is he on an extended vacation in Barbados or Brazil? Abducted by Martians or nursing an ailment? Watch the narrator transition from he to she pronouns as Bill is reintroduced as Lily by the end of the story. It’s that simple. She has a new name and a new look, but inside, she’s still the same clever, funny, kind, cool person she always was. Told in rhyme, Juno shows young readers – and their adults – that the T in LGBTQ+ really doesn’t deserve all the fear and hysteria we are currently seeing.  
 
Here are a few things to consider: 
 
If the trans community makes you uncomfortable, reflect on why that is; what about trans people is so unsettling to you? This has all to do with YOU, not them. 
 
Start reading – inform yourself with stories written by and about trans people; you can start with the picture books on the next slide if you need suggestions.
 
Relate – find a human connection with the stories you read; never forget someone’s humanity, or you’ll lose your own.
 
Chill – remember, that someone else’s sharing their identity has nothing to do with you; so, stop trying to make it about your beliefs, your values, your religion; you can let those things dictate your life, but you don’t get to put it on everyone else.
 
Advocate – if you’re an educator, remember to advocate for all kids in your classrooms and schools; you don’t get to pick and choose; and LGBTQ+ students are in your classrooms and schools whether you know it or not. 
@sourcebookskids #pride #pridemonth #trans #library #librariesofinstagram

What if I told you only girls could checkout books in the top row and only boys can checkout books from the bottom row? Today boys exclaimed, “But I want to read Daisy and the Deadly Flu” and “I’ve read Matilda!” While girls shouted, “Hey! Girls can like Minecraft” and “I’ve read all of Dragon Masters!” One of the final thoughts I share with students at the end of their library orientation just before they go off to explore: There is no such thing as a girl book or a boy book; all books are for everyone. ⭐️ I recall some criticism muttered from one boy to another last year, “You can’t read that (Babysitters Club graphic novel); it’s for girls!” And more often than I’d like to recognize, people message me here if I have recommendations for boys… This assumes all boys like the same things. ⭐️ Ask for books about dinosaurs. Request titles for a mystery lover. Inquire about a sports themed graphic novel. But please, don’t request boy books and girl books. They don’t exist.

What sorts of things do you do to set the tone for your library space? I’m not consistent about many things - I often change what I do year to year, class to class - but I am consistent about one thing - rules and consequences. Every single class period from August to May begins with a recap of the 3 rules and the 3 consequences. The first lesson of the library includes a longer, more thorough explanation of expectations, but during lessons that follow, it only takes 2-3 minutes. I find it to be very impactful - they are clear, concise, and easy to reference and by now most kids know them by heart. Most importantly, kids get that they are necessary in order for everyone to enjoy the library. ⭐️ This year, I made a small poster (swipe to the end) for each classroom to give important reminders to students and teachers alike. Hopefully this will help everyone understand the expectations for independent or small  group visits. #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram

Where are you from? The answer can simply be stated as a location – a city, a state, a country. But, like most things, the answer is never that simple. Where we’re from is layered with stories; the games we play at recess; the way we style our hair; the snacks we eat; the songs we listen to; the people who shout at us to sit down or those that call us honey; the books that stick with us (and those that don’t); the assumptions people make about us – ones that make us second guess who we are; the doodles we draw, the scribbles we make, the notes we take; the meals we share, the memories we make; the laughter that makes our belly shake; the quilts we wrap around our bodies and the arms that do the same. With I’m From, Gary Gray Jr., (@garyrgrayjr) shows us that where we’re from is more than a place… it’s a feeling - as vibrant and textured as one of Oge Mora’s (@oge_mora) colorful collages. Where are you from?
 
🏆I’ve known Gary since my earliest days on Instagram, and it is my honor to feature his debut picture book from @harperkids. Proud of you Gary. Dreams do come true.

Author/illustrator Todd Parr has made a career out of making BIG ideas and feelings – love, peace, joy, gratitude, kindness, family, individuality, worry, grief, loss, and fear – accessible to our youngest readers with his childlike doodles exploding in vibrant primary colors and simple, meaningful text. Now, he’s taken that same talent to the next level to help explain the Inflation Reduction Act to our youngest readers and their grownups too.
 
The Inflation Reduction Act. It’s not something most adults could probably tell you about, so it’s probably one of the last things you’d expect to see a children’s book tackle. But that’s exactly what Parr’s latest book - The Big Hope Plan – sets out to do. It’s a message to our young people, that when we work together, we can set forth a plan to make things better – for ourselves, for our families, for our communities. The plan is BIG and it’s full of HOPE. It’s The Big Hope Plan brought to you by @climatepower and @toddparr.
 
I want to gift one copy of The Big Hope Plan (along with 4 other Todd Parr titles) to one of you for your classroom, school, or home library. We started this lesson by locating Paraguay on the map, and then took a look at scenes from the landfill in Cateura… students described it as filthy, trashy, polluted, messy, smelly, toxic, poor, unclean, unsafe, unhealthy. Then I posed the question, “Can something beautiful come from a landfill?” The great thing about young people is they answered yes… they’re filled with hope. We read Building an Orchestra of Hope by @carmenoliver9013 and @lupencita which details how Favio Chávez taught the children of Cateura, Paraguay to make music from trash. After reading, I played a video clip of Fabio’s students playing their flutes and violins and chimes made from recycled materials… the students called it beautiful, peaceful, hopeful, pretty, calming, joyful… It was a perfect #hispanicheritagemonth read aloud and a message I hope they’ll carry with them for years to come. @faviohernanchavezmoran

I keep a binder of completed directed drawings so I can pull them for different lessons throughout the year. I started these my first year as librarian when I was trying to figure out what to do with kindergarten - a story didn’t suffice, so I started making up drawings on the spot to keep those little people engaged. To my surprise, they did great because - as I tell them all the time - drawing is just putting basic shapes together to create a picture. We love creating art in the style of many children’s book illustrators and breaking down iconic characters into simple shapes.  #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

In fourth grade we are reading What Is A Refugee by Elise Gravel (@elise_gravel) who brilliantly answers the question with her clear, concise writing and kid-friendly illustrations.  At a time when we sing there’s no place like home for the holidays, it’s important for our young people to be aware of the global community - many who have no place to call home. Then we listen to/watch Neil Gaiman read his poem - What You Need to Be Warm. Profits from sales of the book go to help refugees who are between homes, relocated to camps, and forced to flee home because of war, hate, violence, prejudice. After hearing Gaiman read the poem, I have students share something that makes them feel safe, warm, or welcome or something they can do to make others feel those things. It’s a reminder for my students of what they have, and what they can do, and that - as the poem states - everyone has the right to be here. Together their words - on post-it notes - are combined to create a fire… and collectively those words can ignite thought, curiosity, action. Because this holiday season, no matter how or what you celebrate, we can all use a little more love, warmth, and acceptance. The slide has been added to December Slides (link in bio for Google Drive Freebies). #refugees

Another Christmas in the trenches. The story of the Christmas Truce of 1914 is told in two picture books - Christmas in the Trenches by John McCutcheon & And the Soldiers Sang by J. Patrick Lewis. This spectacular tale of historical fiction was the perfect selection for my fifth graders who have recently studied World War I. I showed them a short three minute video that does a great job of re-enacting the event portrayed in the books (I alternated reading both which we have in our collection), and gifted each of them a mini Hersey bar of chocolate. It’s a reminder that warring sides often have more in common than not; the way we delight in the simple joys of joining in a game, the feeling of a fresh  haircut, telling the stories of missed loved ones, the taste of chocolate, a shared feast, singing together. If only the world could peel away all the layers of hate, power, greed, supremacy, prejudice, and violence. Underneath all of it, we all want the same things - to feel love, comfort, and joy. Why do we steal it from each other? ⭐️ Added to December Slides (link in bio to Google Drive Freebies). #history #historicalfiction #library #librariesofinstagram #librarian #librariansofinstagram #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booklife #read #books #bookish #teachersfollowteachers #teachersofinstagram #iteachtoo

Third graders “met” Jennifer Jones - @rockette_jenn - the first African American Rockette! Jennifer opened the door for all girls of color to see themselves in one of the most iconic dance groups in the world. Sharing her story from @harperkids in this new picture book Jennifer addresses feeling different for being in an interracial family, the fight to drown out voices of the haters, and the importance of seeing yourself represented on stage. My students have enjoyed this uplifting success story and, of course, we watched the Rockettes’ performance at this year’s Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade. #rockettes #radiocitymusichall These are part of December Slides.

For 25 years we’ve Googled the answers to our questions, curiosities, and wonderings. For this quarter of a century anniversary, Google compiled the most searched in its 25 year history – the most searched first step, decade, and moment of silence; the most searched sport, athlete, and MVP; the most searched songwriter, performance, and band; the most searched superhero, cartoon, and emoji; the most searched movement, parade, and toy; from scientists and fashion icons to movie casts and rock and roll divas we searched, and searched, and searched. 
 
You’ve probably heard it said, “Librarians were the first Google.” And still, even with existence of internet search engines, we continue to help kids search for their answers, their interests, their dreams; search for an escape; way in, a way out, and a way through. 
 
Other than computers to search the catalog, my school library remains analog. Books – tangible, hold-in-your hands, bound together, page-turning books, still hold what we search for… so, search on. 
 
Get these book peekers and posters for a back to school display this January. What will you search for in 2024? Link in bio – Google Drive Freebies – Book Displays – 25 Years of Google.

With grades 3-5 this week, I’m sharing about MLK and the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.  With fourth and fifth grade, we will be reading stories about some of Martin’s friends, family, and allies (see slide 3)… this helps me not get bored reading the same story, and I feel by this age, kids have heard many MLK stories, but they have heard less about these people who helped him spread his message and work. With third grade, we will read stories about marching and protesting and using our voices to speak up about the things that are important to us. Finally, I’ll ask all students to share some ideas and thoughts in response to some prompts (see the last slide). These are in my Google Drive Freebies (link in bio) in the Google Slides folder. Some books are linked but to my personal kindle cloud library.
